question.text: An ___ training period will be instituted in July.

answer.explanation: (B) “Training period” can be modified by the past participle “extended”. Choice (A) is a verb. Choices (C) and (D) are nouns.
(C) This is the adjective form, used to describe the noun “businessperson”. Choices (A) and (D) are nouns. Choice (B) is a verb.

question.text: The ___ of the new buildine will start next month.

answer.explanation: (B) “The” must be followed by a noun. Choice (A) is an adjective. Choices (C) and (D) are verbs.

question.text: ___ she left the ship, the purser signed out.

answer.explanation: (D) “Before" establishes a logical time relationship between the two past tense verbs. Choices (A) and (B) do not make sense. Choice (C) would establish an illogical equal relationship.

question.text: Before using your savings ___ borrowing money to start a business, you should carefully evaluate the financial risks involved.

answer.explanation: The two verbs use the same form so we choose "or".

question.text: Your selection will arrive in seven to ten days and will be followed by ___ deliveries every six weeks.
You will find all the pencils you need___that drawer.

answer.explanation: (D) The pencils are inside, or in, the drawer. Choice (A) describes movement from one side to another. Choices (B) and (C) are extremely unlikely places to find a pencil relative to a drawer.

question.text: Liza Baley recently ___ positive reviews for her performance in Mike Keric’s new drama, Nightfall.

answer.explanation: We use "recently" with past tenses or present perfect tense. Because the continuous form of the verb "receive" is only used for signals (sound, wave), we choose "received".

question.text: Many subscribers have requested that we ___ the journals to their offices.

answer.explanation: (C) “Request” is followed by the simple form of the verb when it means that one person or group (subscribers) made another person or group (we) do something. Choice (A) is a present form. Choice (B) is a past form. Choice (D) is a progressive form.
(A) “On” is a preposition meaning “upon the surface of” Choice (B) indicates movement across something. Choice (C) means “to place inside”. Choice (D) means “lacking”.
